FedEx Earnings Mixed, Cuts Fiscal 2016 View
FedEx Corp. reported disappointing quarterly results, cutting its profit outlook for the year as demand for transport services weakened and costs rose at its ground-delivery business.
The company also said it plans to hire around 55,000 seasonal workers for the holiday period.
In the same period last year, FedEx announced it would hire 50,000 seasonal workers for the holidays.
The stock was down about 2.5% in premarket trade, 45 minutes before the opening bell on Wednesday.
FedEx Corp. said it expects to earn between $10.40 and $10.90 for its fiscal year ending in May 2016, down 20 cents from its previous estimate.
Analysts were expecting $10.84, according to a survey by FactSet.

The downward revision comes despite the average 4.9% price increases that took effect January 4 and higher surcharges for the land transport of large and heavy packages that will take effect in November.
The company said it still expects an increase in earnings compared to the previous year as a result of cost reductions, higher revenues and the development of online trade.
Chairman and CEO Fred Smith said the “company is facing a significantly worse global macroeconomic environment than anticipated, particularly with respect to production and global trade.”
The hiring plans were announced a day after UPS rival FedEx said it plans to hire 90,000-95,000 seasonal workers, about the same number it hired last year.
FedEx earned 692 million dollars in the quarter ended August 31, up 6% from a year earlier.
Earnings per share came to $2.42, below the $2.44 per share average estimate of 12 analysts surveyed by Zacks Investment Research.
Profit rose 5 percent to $12.3 billion.
Six analysts surveyed by Zacks had predicted revenue of $12.23 billion.
FedEx has been hit in recent years by a decline in international priority shipping that has led to flat revenue for its Express unit.
But the explosive growth in online shopping drove FedEx Ground's results.
In the fourth quarter, ground segment revenues climbed 29%, but operating profits were flat as costs rose for big boxes and self-insurance.
The express unit recorded higher revenue due to higher base rates, while freight revenue declined due to higher costs.
In pre-market trading, about an hour before the opening bell, FedEx stock was down $3.85, or 2.5%, at $150.15.
By Tuesday's close they had fallen 11 percent this year and 17 percent off a June 11 all-time high.

In the most anticipated meeting in years, Federal Reserve policymakers will gather around a 27-foot Honduran mahogany table for two days this week to decide whether it is time to raise a key interest rate for the first time in nearly a decade.
Above them, in the back of the central bank's boardroom, will loom a mural of the United States.
The map is meant to remind Janet L. Yellen, the Fed chairwoman, and her colleagues that they must put the nation’s economic interests above all else.
The Federal Reserve has a dual mandate from Congress: to maximize employment in the United States and to maintain price stability.
But in the aftermath of the Great Recession, central bank leaders have affirmed there is a third, unwritten mandate: financial stability.

And this third factor could be the X factor in a too-close-to-call decision that will be announced Tuesday, and that will decide whether the U.S. economy is ready to be weaned off the unprecedented stimulus provided by the near-zero short-term interest rate in place since late 2008.

Even as most of the data points to a strong U.S. economy, the recent turmoil in global financial markets could spook Fed officials already wary of adding volatility by raising the federal funds rate - even by a quarter of a percentage point.
"Clearly, the labor market and inflation are going to be the first and foremost items they're going to be watching," said Lindsey M. Piegza, chief economist at brokerage firm Stifel Nicolaus & Co.
“But I do think if they're looking for an excuse not to raise rates, the rising uncertainty in the global economy is enough to give them ammunition to wait,” she said.
There is no consensus on what Fed will decide, and that itself has caused some instability in financial markets.
About half of economists surveyed by Bloomberg recently anticipated an interest rate rise this week.
But financial markets are expecting Fed to hold off, with one key indicator showing the probability of a hike at just 30 percent.
It would indicate a selloff on the stock market if the Fed raises the interest rate, unless policymakers soften the blow by promising it will be a very long time until the next hike.
On Tuesday, the industrial average Dow Jones gained 228.89 points, or 1.4 percent, to 16,599.85.
The momentum was driven by expectations that Fed policymakers will keep the benchmark interest rate on hold this week, said John Lonski, chief economist at Moody's Capital Markets Research Group.
It would be surprising if the Fed raised rates at this point, Lonski said.
If Fed policymakers do this, “they should act deeply in their policies to avoid panic in financial markets.”
Other experts said an interest rate hike would calm financial markets because it would remove uncertainty about when the Fed will act.

Just a month ago, the Fed seemed on track to raise rates by a quarter percentage point this month, the first small step toward a gradual tightening that would signal the strength of the U.S. recovery.
Yellen had said in the spring and early summer she expected a rate increase this year despite objections from liberals that more economic progress was needed.
Although job creation slowed in August, the labor market remains healthy this year.
The unemployment rate fell to 5.1% last month, the lowest level in more than seven years and nearly at the level the Federal Reserve considers full employment.
Wage gains were showing signs of an uptick.
And although inflation continued to fall short of the central bank's annual target, Fed policymakers said a key reason was the temporary effect of plummeting oil prices.
"The economy can withstand higher rates and it needs them, given the tightness in the labor market," said Ian Shepherdson, chief economist at Pantheon Macroeconomics.
However, financial markets around the world began jittering at the end of last month, after China depreciated its currency.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average has fallen 16 percent off its May record high as investors worried that China's slowing economy will drag down global growth.
The market has pulled back somewhat this month, with the Dow index now about 10 percent below its May peak.
For Fed policymakers, market turmoil adds to the complex calculus of when to raise rates.

“Without what has happened in financial markets and the news about weakening Chinese economy in the last few weeks, they would have been more firm in their statement,” said Stephen D. Oliner, an experienced researcher at the UCLA Ziman Center for Real Estate and a former Fed official.
Now, he is forecasting that it will take at least another month for them to manage the effects better.
"There's a lot of uncertainty about how much of the impact on the U.S. economy will be, and there are not a lot of data points to go on subsequent to the developments in China," Oliner said.
Global economic well-being is not a major Fed concern, so it should not be a consideration in the decisionmaking.
But in reality, the Fed is becoming a global monetary authority.
In recent years, the central bank has wielded enormous influence.
Bernanke merely hinted in 2013 that the Fed might "taper" its monetary expansion, causing a global market earthquake.

In a world where markets and economies are increasingly intertwined, it is no wonder that Fed officials not only watch developments abroad but also consult with other central banks and experts to get a better handle on the world economy.
"It's more art than science at this point," said Zachary Karabell, chief economist of the wealth management firm, Envestnet Inc.

Jeffrey Lacker, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Richmond, Va., said this month that “the Fed has a history of overreacting to financial market changes that don't seem to be connected to the economic fundamentals.”
Lacker, a voting member of the Federal Open Market Committee, the policymaking body, who supported interest rates increases, offered the 1998-99 decisions as an example.

The Federal Reserve reduced its benchmark interest rate by 0.75 percentage point over three meetings in 1998, when Asia was in a financial crisis, “despite the possible limited implications for U.S. developments,” Lacker said.
A year later, the Fed officials reversed course.

The Fed should put financial stability at the top of its agenda only in case of a major crisis, such as the 2008 market quake, said Adam S. Posen, a former member of the Bank of England's rate-setting committee.
The recent turmoil is nowhere near that level, he said.
“We certainly do not want to be in a situation where we are worried about a rate rise because the markets are upset,” said Posen, the president of the Peterson Institute for International Economics.
The Federal Reserve Act still holds the dual mandate, and it doesn't mention financial stability, and until that changes, I don't think it should be taking any preemptive action.
Are you looking for an extraordinary market with a Thai theme?
Try LAX-C in Chinatown.
Yes, Chinatown
The open-air market that opened in 1997 belongs to LAX-C Inc.
Often called the Thai Costco, LAX-C is a wholesale market, but it's open to the public.
Yes, it's in Chinatown, not in Thai Town.

The market/depot is a sprawling store that offers an amazing range of fresh, frozen and dried products, popular Thai and Asian snacks, kitchenware and cookware, furniture, religious and festive decorations.
There's also an auto mall if you want to buy some motor oil.
The shop is huge, and it takes at least an hour to get through all the aisles.
If you get hungry from all of the shopping, eat at LAX-C BBQ Express.
The store's inner food district (good, affordable) is close to houses and offers more options of takeout food.
What's in stock: Do you need something - anything- Thai?
You probably find it at LAX-C.
It has reasonable prices and certain items are sold wholesale.
Fresh produce includes herbs, fruits and other Asian and Thai products.
There is a large meat station, similar to the fish station - the serving staff will clean and filet the fish and will even fry it for you if you wish.

A large part of the store is dedicated to the huge freezer section, where you will find frozen curry leaves, watermelon and ginger, whole ducks, fish, blood and ox balls, pork carcasses, fishballs, traditional sausages, semi-prepared ingredients and many more.
Who buys from there: Restaurant owners and head cooks, also families and individuals.
The wide aisles can accommodate both shopping trolleys and forklifts.
Discovery: Fresh Durian fruits just next to the residential area.
Where it is: The store is in an industrial part of L.A. on the outskirts of Chinatown and Downtown -- a few streets from Philippe The Original.
Parking: LAX-C has its own parking area shared with other shops and restaurants.
While the store may get crowded, you usually have no trouble finding a place to park.

4 people died after police fired rubber bullets at protesters in Nepal

Four people, including a 4-year-old boy, have been killed in southern Nepal after police fired rubber bullets at protesters demonstrating against the country's proposed new constitution, an official said Wednesday.
The violence occurred on Tuesday evening in the Rupandehi district, some 280 kilometers west of Kathmandu.
According to Bishnu Prasad Dhakal, the district police chief, more than 1,000 protestors had gathered in front of a police station and some of them threw stones and petrol bombs.
Mr. Dhakal said police used tear gas and fired warning shots before resorting to rubber bullets.
He said 20 police officers and five civilians were injured.
It was not immediately clear why rubber bullets, which can kill but are usually used as a less lethal alternative, caused so many deaths.

The clash was the latest incident in weeks of violent protests in Nepal's southern region, where members of the Madhesi ethnic group say the new provinces created under the new constitution would dilute their political influence.
Protests have also been held in western Nepal where the ethnic Tharu group is demanding its own state.
At least 40 people, including 11 police officers, have been killed in the violence that began August 10.

when four major political parties signed an accord to divide the country into provinces -- a major step towards a new Constitution but a highly contentious issue in Nepal, a country ruled centrally for centuries.
The process to draft a new constitution was launched in 2008, but lawmakers accelerated it after a devastating earthquake killed thousands of people in April.
Lawmakers in Kathmandu have voted on the clauses of a constitution bill and officials say the new charter could be adopted Sunday.

NHC: 60% chance of cyclone to the south of the Cape Verde Islands

A broad low-pressure area about 560 miles south of the southernmost Cape Verde Islands has a 60 percent chance of becoming a tropical cyclone in the next 48 hours, the U.S. National Hurricane Center said Tuesday.

Weight-Loss Surgery May Help Some Mildly Obese Diabetics
The benefits of weight-loss surgery in people with mild obesity and type 2 diabetes may be maintained for at least five years, a new study suggests.
It's still too early to say if diabetics with moderate obesity live longer after weight-loss surgery than those on non-surgical treatment.
"It takes a long time to centralize the mortality data," said Dr. Robin Blackstone, a bariatric surgeon who wrote an accompanying commentary in JAMA Surgery.
Weight-loss surgeries, also known as bariatric surgeries, use different methods to reduce the size of the stomach.
They reduce the feeling of being hungry and limit the body's ability to absorb food.
Bariatric surgery has proven effective in treating type 2 diabetes in the past, but most studies have been conducted on patients with a body mass index of 35 or greater.
BMI, a measure of weight in relation to height, is considered normal from 18.5 to 24.9.
A BMI of at least 25 indicates a person is overweight and people with BMI over 30 are considered obese.
You can calculate your BMI at: 1.usa.gov/1D0ZqDv.

For the new study, researchers from Min-Sheng General Hospital in Taiwan used data gathered after 2007 from a trial comparing two types of bariatric surgery -- gastric bypass and gastric sleeve -- for treating type 2 diabetes in people with mild obesity.
The average BMI among the patients who underwent surgery fell from 31 to 24.5 by the end of the fifth year of the study.
Meanwhile, the percentage of adults receiving non-surgical treatment for diabetes remained at nearly 29 percent.
Of those who had surgery, diabetes was completely resolved in 36 percent and partially resolved in 28 percent.
In the medical treatment group, by comparison, diabetes was completely cured in only 1 percent and partially in only 2 percent of the subjects.
In addition, blood pressure control, triglycerides, and "bad" LDL cholesterol "were generally better in the surgery group," the authors concluded.
The researchers also measured the blood hemoglobin A1c level, which reflects blood glucose levels over time.
Researchers write that the optimal level of hemoglobin A1c is under 7%.
After the surgery, the average hemoglobin A1C level dropped from about 9% to about 6%.
But in the group treated with medicine, the rate stayed at about 8%.

But this "glycemic control" -- reflected by improved hemoglobin A1c levels -- did not reduce the rate of death at five years, according to Dr. Chih-Cheng Hsu, the study's lead researcher, and his colleagues.
The research team also compared the average outcomes associated with the two types of surgical intervention.

At 5 years, the RYGB group had lost more weight (18.7 kg vs 14.2 kg) and had greater reductions in BMI (7.4 vs 5.1) and HbA1c (3.1% vs 2.1%) and had a higher probability of complete diabetes remission (46.9% vs 16.7%) than the sleeve gastrectomy group.

While the new study doesn't show a survival or surgery benefit at five years, there's evidence from a study in Sweden on people with severe obesity that surgery prolongs life, Blackstone of the University of Arizona College of Medicine - Phoenix said.
In the Swedish study, obese people who had bariatric surgery were about 29% less likely to die after 15 years compared with a group that tried more conventional methods.

Although the new study did not indicate a survival benefit for patients who underwent surgery, Blackstone said it is an optimistic finding for people with BMIs below 35 who are interested in the procedure.

“This is the point where this paper is critical because it states that this surgical intervention is safe in the group with lower BMI,” without increasing the risk of death or kidney disease, she says.
Blackstone said that patients and their doctors should start taking weight seriously when a patient's body mass index, or BMI, hits 27 or 30.
“I think we wait way too long to urge people to take this seriously,” she said.
I think that once they accumulate these genetic changes that short-circuit their bodies and make them prone to obesity and diabetes, it's extremely difficult to reverse it.
„It is impossible for everyone to come to Europe” - Dalai Lama - RT news
Europe can't take in all the refugees, the Dalai Lama said, adding that the real solution to the current refugee crisis is in the Middle East.
The Tibetan Buddhist leader has issued an appeal to end violence in the mother countries of refugees.

The Dalai Lama has spoken about the current refugee crisis in a speech at the opening of the Dalai Lama Centre for Compassion in Oxford, dedicated to the study of ethics, at the start of his 10-day visit to the UK.
He said that at the present time, the interests of humanity should prevail over the interests of each particular nation, and even of each continent.
He also stressed that, while admirable, the response of western European countries to the refugee crisis is inadequate.
"It's impossible for everybody to come to Europe," he said in his speech.
While the Dalai Lama praised Germany's and Austria's efforts to deal with the crisis, he said it is a temporary solution.

"It is wonderful that there is so much care for a few thousand refugees, but we must at the same time think of long-term solutions, to bring genuine peace and development, especially through education, to Muslim countries," he said.
Bottom line, we've got to think of ways to reduce crime in their countries.
We have to reduce the use of force.
Force has never resolved these problems." he added.

On the issue of violence, the Dalai Lama also commented on George W. Bush's actions after the September 11, 2001 attacks, saying the United States' violent response had unleashed a chain of uncontrollable events.
After September 11th, I wrote a letter to President Bush expressing my condolences and telling him to resolve this without violence.
I know his motives were strong, but he used force and generated unexpected consequences," Dalai Lama said.
Fourfold Increase in Children Ingesting Hand Sanitizers in Past Four Years

According to the Georgia Poison Center, U.S. poison control centers have reported a nearly 400% increase since 2010 in the number of children under age 12 who swallowed liquid hand sanitizers with high alcohol content.
According to Dr. Gaylord Lopez, director of the Georgia Poison Center, the cases of children under 12 ingesting detergent reported to poison centers rose from 3,266 in 2010 to 16,117 in 2014.
"The kids are accessing these products more frequently and unfortunately they are ending up in the emergency room," Lopez said.
Lopez said some children intentionally drink detergent and others do so in order to impress their friends or to answer challenges on social media.
YouTube videos show teenagers drinking detergent to make cheap drinks.
It seems that teenagers mixed the detergent with mouthwash containing alcohol in order to obtain a stronger drink.
Children under age may be attracted by the appealing smell of the detergent.
„A kid does not think that he is doing harm,” Lopez said.
Many of the most attractive types are those that are perfumed.
Strawberry, grape and orange-scented hand cleansers are the most attractive to children.
Hand sanitizer contains about 45-95% alcohol.
Even a few small swallows of alcohol can poison young children.
"It's very concentrated alcohol," said Stephen Thornton, the medical director at the Kansas University Medical Center's poison control center, told Fox 4 Kansas City.

This way, we avoid leaving a shot glass of whiskey on the table but people are leaving these hand sanitizers out in the open, so if a young kid gets to them, it's a quick way to consume a lot of alcohol.

Hewlett-Packard to Cut 30,000 Jobs
Hewlett-Packard is expected to lay off between 25,000 and 30,000 workers as part of efforts to restructure and cut costs in its services sector.
This year, HP will split into two companies, separating its personal computer and printer division from its fast-growing corporate hardware and services operations.
The layoffs will result in $2.7 billion in costs beginning in the fourth quarter, the company said.
"These restructuring actions will further HPE's competitive and cost position as a new company," said Meg Whitman, HP's president and chief executive officer, who will lead the unit after the split.
"Hewlett Packard Enterprise will be smaller and more focused than HP is today and will have a portfolio of businesses that will provide the foundation for the New Style of IT," Whitman said.
As a separate company, we are positioned better than ever to meet the growing needs of our global customers.
The company said the spin-off will generate more than $50 billion in annual revenues and “will offer integrated solutions with no rival.”

A company founded in 1930 by Stanford University graduates, Bill Hewlett and Dave Packard, specializing in the production of electric equipment whose garage in Palo Alto was called the "cradle of Silicon Valley" splits into two.
HP has undergone a massive reorganization to adapt to the shift from traditional computers to mobile devices.

The move by HP, the world's second-largest computer maker and one of the United States' best-known technology companies, is the latest in a trend of breaking up companies in the belief that focused companies perform better.
FriendsFest: Comedy Series that Taught Us Important Lessons About Friendship Between Men
The absence of similar figures in TV shows is all the more glaring given that the need for men to open up is now more pressing than ever, with suicide rates among young men hitting a 15-year high.
Suicide was the main cause of death for British men aged 20-45 in 2013 and remains three times more common in men than women.

In an attempt to tackle the problem, Campaign Against Living Miserably (CALM) has declared 2015 the Year of the Male, seeking to challenge the culture that prevents men from seeking help when they need it.
Friendship is at the center of the struggle to achieve this challenge.

A recent study involving more than 2,000 high school students with depression symptoms found that if the patient was surrounded by enough friends with “a healthy mood,” their chances of recovery doubled.
Also, for those who are not depressed, a circle of mentally healthy friends halves the risk of mental disorders.
Friendship, of course, to have an effect, this must first be accessible.
In this social media-dominated era of style over substance, the immediate nature of a response often takes precedence over one with meaning.
Our digital lives have doubled the need to create the appearance of a strong, fun and successful personality, even though in reality isolation is the norm.

This superficial success is dominated by what psychologists call extrinsic values; money, image, social status, all at the cost of intrinsic values - our inner desire for personal development and friendship - which more deeply affect our mental health.
Billionaire video game inventor has recently explained that money doesn't buy happiness.
The beauty of the show Friends was that it put a spotlight on this idea.
The characters were not defined by their jobs but by their personalities, which they showed by interacting with each other as friends.

Joey and Chandler's frequent bromance, the times they sit down to watch football in their comfy armchairs, and Ross's passion for Rachel, all come from the fact that men can relate to this situation, even if they often shy away from exploring their feelings fully.
As one social worker explained to me: ...my role as a listener to suicidal and depressed people showed how even the smallest interactions with friends can make a difference.
People who ring us often don't feel they can talk to family and friends.
The old adage of "suck it up" is strong, as is the perception that you're weak if you speak openly about your problems.
Friends is one of the shows that springs to mind when I try to provide more long-term psychological coping mechanisms.
The series highlighted the small moments of camaraderie between men.
As much as objective external intervention helps, by phone, people who find themselves in moments of despair, sustained support for the long term comes from family and close friends.
So if you're heading to FriendsFest this weekend, organised by Comedy Central, with full recreations of the sets to celebrate the occasion, why not invite your friends over to Central Perk.
Or, even better, if you see someone alone at Starbucks, smile and say hello.
You never know what difference your friendship could make.
Comedy Central is airing all 236 episodes of Friends as part of the #FriendsFest celebration.

Xi Urges Wider Global Engagement of Economy
President Xi Jinping said Tuesday to a group in charge of reform that the economy must open wider to the outside world to feed growth.
“China needs to engage in and attract foreign investment and expertise, and improve its opening policies,” Xi said at the 16th meeting of the Central Leading Group for Deepening Overall Reform.
Promoting openness and encouraging reforms will bring new impetus and vitality and make room for economic growth, Xi said.

The leading group adopted a series of guidelines, including a negative list for market access, easing customs clearance policies, encouraging state-owned enterprises to absorb private capital and reorganizing the resident registration system.
The statement said there will be a negative list that will identify sectors and activities off-limits to investment.
The system will undergo a gradual roll-out, with testing and improvements through pilot programs.

The measure is important because it will give the market a greater role in resource allocation, ensuring a rule-based business environment and providing a wider opening to the market, the statement said.
State authorities will also weaken controls over the powers they delegate to companies, ensuring that these companies decide how they run their businesses.
China will also allow border regions to explore new models of cross-border economic cooperation and new mechanisms for promoting regional growth, the statement said.
In an effort to open up state-controlled sectors, several sectors will open up to private investment.

"The state authorities will not change its policy concerning foreign investment and will protect legitimate interests of foreign-invested companies, and offer them better services," the statement said.

The new system will also make it easier for foreign nationals to apply for permanent residence permits, also known as green cards, by streamlining the requirements and speeding up the application process.

Premier Li Keqiang and top leaders Liu Yunshan and Zhang Gaoli also attended the meeting, according to a statement issued after the meeting.

Air India is to sack around 130 cabin crew for being overweight, the company announced late last week.

The state-owned company said the decision was made for security and recent government regulation purposes, but critics say the measure is “ridiculous” and “shockingly sexist,” according to The Washington Post.
The mass firing is the latest in a decade-long battle between the company and its heavier flight attendants.
The limit dates from the 1980s, when Air India started using charts with ideal weight and height.

The flight attendants sued the airline and won their jobs back, but were laid off again in 2009.

200 companies are expected to participate in the autumn edition of the Career Fair (TdC), to take place in Brasov, Chisinau, Cluj-Napoca, Iasi, Sibiu and Tirgu-Mures.

An Italian was caught at Bors border with immigrants hidden in his truck.
Two Sri Lankans were caught at the Bors border crossing on Monday as they were trying to illegally cross the border, hidden in a semi-trailer truck driven by an Italian.
The two of them had paid the driver 4,000 euros to be transported to France, the Border Police says.

During the specific check, border police noticed in the cabin of the truck a large traveling bag, which contained personal belongings of multiple persons, reason why they undertook a detailed check of the means of transport.
Police discovered two men hidden among the plastic barrels in the trailer of the truck.
The investigation has revealed that the two men, aged 28, are Sri Lankan nationals and asylum seekers in Romania.

"During investigations, the young people declared they intended to get to France, for which they contacted a countryman, through whom they met with an Italian driver, who offered to take them to their destination, where they were to receive 2,000 euros each," reads the communiqué of the Border Police.
The two migrants have been indicted for "attempting to illegally cross the state border".

How satisfied are Romanians in the couple: Men versus women
Most Romanians are happy with their relationships.
That's the conclusion of a study conducted on the occasion of John Gray's visit to Romania, the author of the bestselling book "Men are from Mars, Women are from Venus".
A total of 62% of respondents were "very satisfied" and "satisfied" with the overall quality of their relationship.

"However, 18 percent said they were 'slightly dissatisfied' and 'very dissatisfied' with their relationship, while 18 percent said they were 'just right'", the study concluded, according to a statement sent to Ziare.com on Tuesday.
The situation is somewhat different when men's and women's responses are analyzed separately.
So, 28 percent of men are very satisfied, 39 percent satisfied, 17 percent about right, 6 percent very dissatisfied and 8 percent dissatisfied.
For women, 33 percent declared themselves satisfied, 24 percent very satisfied, 8 percent very dissatisfied, 14 percent slightly dissatisfied and 19 percent chose the right category.
When we look at the degree of satisfaction (positive), we will notice that men are more satisfied.
As regards the neutral (right) state, we see a difference of two percent.
"The same also applies to the greatly unsatisfied category, where the biggest difference is recorded for the somewhat unsatisfied category at 6%," the release also said.
The study also showed that one quarter of Romanians (26%) spend one hour or less together, 18% spend between five and eight hours together, and 45% spend between two and four hours together.

The study's authors also said "Romanians feel the need for more adventure in their lives (24%), followed by affection (21%), money (21%), safety (20%), something new (19%), sex (19%), respect 18%, trust 17%, pleasure 17%, connection 17%, knowledge 16%, protection 14%, importance 14%, learning 12%, freedom 11%, self-knowledge 10% and control 7%".
The study was carried out by Extreme Training between 1 June and 1 September on 1,369 people, with a 2.6% margin of error.

Thousands of people have paid respects by laying flowers

Thousands of people have visited the coffin of Corneliu Vadim Tudor, so many that there have never been so many at the Saint George's Church, except when the church was reconsecrated or during the Great Feast of Saint Nicholas, says parish priest Emil Caramizaru.

Hundreds of people of all ages are waiting in line, which stretches from the entrance of the church all the way to the side streets, to pass by the catafalque, on which the lifeless body of Corneliu Vadim Tudor lies.
People are waiting for about an hour to get into St. George New Church, where 40 people are let in at a time.
Approximately 300 people per hour passed by the coffin with the body of Corneliu Vadim Tudor on Wednesday.

Thousands of people from Bucharest, but also from Cluj, Baia Mare, Iasi, Constanta and Craiova came on Tuesday to bring an homage to Corneliu Vadim Tudor, so many people we hadn't had except at the re-consecration of 300 years of the Church and the Great Holyday of St. Nicholas.

"Corneliu Vadim Tudor was at the 300-year anniversary of the church and he was next to the members of the Holy Synod, the Most Blessed Daniel and representatives of the five patriarchs who participated in the reconsecration," said the priest of the parish of the church in the capital, Emil Caramizaru.
He said people came with flowers and candles in their hands, stood quietly and waited their turn, as if on a religious high holiday.
It is extraordinary how people are behaving, standing in line, dignified, with children, the very old, people in wheelchairs, as if it was a religious celebration.
"It's overwhelming to see them waiting to pay their last respects to Vadim Tudor," the parish priest, Emil Caramizaru, told Reuters.

According to the priest, at the family's request, the church will remain open also Wednesday night into Thursday, after being closed on Tuesday night at 1 a.m. local time and reopened in the morning at 7 a.m.

The funeral of Vadim Tudor, the President of the nationalist Greater Romania Party (PRM) will take place on Wednesday and Thursday, the head of the party's National Council, Constantin Zota, declared on Tuesday.

The parish priest said that Vadim Tudor came to the church very often, especially in the evenings, after 8 p.m. and he asked him every time to open the reliquary with the relics of Saint Nicholas, and then he remained there to pray for a few minutes.
He came here very often, mostly in the evening, after 20.00, he asked me to open the shrine with the Saint Nicholas relics and he prayed.
He said that it was a great blessing this Brancoveanu's church.
He told me: "Think, dear brother Emil, that here were Brancoveanu, Eminescu, Mihai Viteazul, who carried the hand of St. Nicholas."
"'Imagine what a blessing for this country,' Vadim told me,' the priest said.
Corneliu Vadim Tudor is to be buried on Thursday at Ghencea Civil Cemetery, with full military honours.
The Senate leadership on Tuesday rejected the request of the wife of the late Senator Corneliu Vadim Tudor that the coffin with his body be placed in the corridor of the legislative chamber.
Corneliu Vadim Tudor was born on November 28, 1949, in Bucharest, was a writer, politician and journalist.
He was the founder of Romania's Greater Romania Party, a former member of the European Parliament and a former senator.

Victor Piturca revealed how he parted ways with the Romanian national team last fall.

Tanks and Water Cannons at the Border

Hungarian police have deployed Humvee military vehicles equipped with machine guns to the border with Serbia after clashes Wednesday when water cannons and tear gas were used against immigrants trying to cross over despite a razor-wire fence.
At least 20 police officers and two children were injured in clashes, Russia Today reports.
So far 20 police have been injured and ambulance services have treated two children who were thrown over the security fence.
"We will rebuild the fence and strengthen it further, and we will protect the security of Hungary by all means," said the Hungarian Prime Minister's security advisor Gyorgy Bakondi.
Police tried to contain the crowd with water cannons and tear gas, as the crowd threw plastic bottles, stones and chunks of pavement.
Authorities reported that dozens of migrants broke down a fence between the towns of Roszke and Horgos and were able to enter the country.
Hungarian Foreign Minister Peter Szijjarto has called on Serbia to take action against "very aggressive" migrants on their shared border.
Reports say Serbian forces have also bolstered their police presence on the border.
Following Wednesday's incidents, Budapest has suspended the transit at Roszke-Horgos border crossing for 30 days.
Hungary is in a concerted action to close its borders to stave off the influx of immigrants.

While on Tuesday he announced he would build a barbed-wire fence along the border with Serbia, in response to vehement protests from Bucharest, on Wednesday the Hungarian Prime Minister announced he would build a fence along the border with Croatia.
Rare Disease Suffering Man
American Nick Hess was suspect by his family to be an alcoholic, his wife even filming him when drunk, barely able to stand and hardly able to speak.
Although the 35-year-old man claimed he had not been drinking, it was clear he was intoxicated.
When she first accused me of being drunk, without me having drunk, I thought she was crazy.
"But his friends and family thought 'maybe he was a secret drinker, maybe he was an alcoholic'," he told the Mirror.
When he watched the videos his wife had made of him, the man from Columbus, Ohio simply did not recognize himself: "I was looking in my eyes and I wasn't there."
"It was awful, I don't remember anything."
Moreover, his wife, although she had doubted him for a while, finally went with him to numerous doctors, remembers that Nick's breath also smelled like alcohol.
Nick's moment of clarity came after a minor accident in which he was hit by another car and found himself three times over the legal limit, though he says he had only one beer the night before.
After years and countless investigations, it was discovered that Nick suffers from an extremely rare disease, "Auto-brewery syndrome".
In fact, her organism makes all carbohydrates consumed ferment, turning into alcohol.
It was his wife who suspected the disease.
There is no cure for the disease, but since Nick changed his diet and cut out carbs he hasn't had an episode.
He wrecked a Mercedes with a golf club
A South Korean man has destroyed his $200,000 Mercedes S63 AMG Coupe in protest of what he says is poor customer service.
The man attacked his car with a golf club, causing so much damage that it was rendered unroadworthy, BT reports.
The entire scene was filmed and the video posted online, to the amusement of those who watched it.

The government approved on Wednesday the "National Immigration Strategy for the Period 2015-2018" and the "Action Plan for 2015", documents that are considered to be "another stage in Romania's efforts to modernize the process of managing immigration on the country's territory", according to a press release.

The source said the strategy aims to efficiently manage immigration, including general strategic objectives, specific objectives and action lines that reflect the policies established at the European level, adapted to national realities.

In view of the problems facing the countries in Romania's immediate neighbourhood, measures are being considered for the unified, coherent management of situations resulting from the possible arrival of illegal immigrants on Romania's territory, caused by political, social, economic or military crises.

"Romanian authorities will contribute to creating a flexible admission system, but at the same time will pay special attention to citizens coming from states with migration potential or who may affect national security," the source added.

The strategy cites a series of factors which could influence immigration and asylum, such as the ongoing conflict in Syria, the reactivation of the conflict in Iraq, the maintenance of an unstable situation in areas near Romania (Ukraine, Transnistria), the perpetuation and intensification of the armed Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

On the other hand, the document also sets a few general strategic objectives regarding immigration, such as: promoting legal migration, more rigorous control of the legality of the stay of third-state citizens on Romanian territory, the proper application of removal measures and restrictive measures, and improving the national asylum system.
The National Strategy includes specific objectives relevant to the transposition and implementation of the general strategic objectives.

Among these are: to facilitate access to the territory of Romania for third-country nationals who respond to the needs of the labor force, to favor the access of third-country nationals to higher education institutions in Romania for the fields and professions identified as being in deficit.
On the 2015 Action Plan, the Government considers it "a means of setting out concrete activities that will lead to a flexible system for stemming the rise in migration".
Romania, in a European labor market ranking

Latvia, Romania and Bulgaria recorded the highest increase in the total cost of labour from the member states of the European Union, in the second quarter of the year, compared to the same period in 2014, according to data published Wednesday by the European Statistical Office (Eurostat).
The index refers to the employers' personnel costs.
The European Union and the euro zone saw the total hourly labor costs go up by 1.9 percent and by 1.6 percent, respectively, for the April-June 2015 period.
Romania ranks 3rd in EU in labor cost growth
The largest increases were registered in Latvia (7.9 percent), Romania (7.7 percent), Bulgaria (6.8 percent), Estonia (5.5 percent) and Lithuania (4.3 percent).
The only EU states where the hourly labour cost dropped in the second quarter of this year were Greece (down 2.9 percent), Cyprus (down 1.2 percent) and Italy (down 0.4 percent).
The increases in labor cost in Romania in April-June 2015 were mainly due to the rise in hourly labor cost in industry and services, by 7.9% and 7.6% respectively.
In the construction sector, Romania registered a 5.8% increase in the hourly labour cost.
TVR Management's Work Report Rejected in Committees: Stelian Tanase Facing Dismissal
The parliamentary culture committees rejected on Wednesday the activity report of the Board of Administration of the Romanian Television Society for 2014.
Seventeen MPs voted for the rejection of the report, one was against it (senator Varujan Vosganian) and one abstained.
The draft report will be submitted to the joint permanent offices.
They are expected to decide next week.
The next plenary meeting will discuss it.
"Given the circumstances I think it will be done fast", said Senator Georgica Severin, head of the Senate's Culture Committee.
He said: "It is common sense that the leadership of the TVR should also be here, as none of its representatives were present at the Culture Committee meeting."
It would have been smart to have the leadership of the Romanian Television present because no one here was subjected to personal attack or anything of that sort.

The invitation was made to CA members since yesterday evening, with an approximate hour because we did not know the hour either, but today, after the joint meeting of the Bureaux, I personally sent a fax to the management of the TVR, inviting it.
I believe that when you are summoned, being a budget employee, paid by public taxes and you are summoned to a meeting of the joint commissions, even if you do not like it you come.
"It is your duty as a secretary of state to appear before Parliament," Severin said after the joint committees of culture of Parliament held a meeting.
He added that during the meeting, the financial aspects of the institution were discussed on the basis of the negative report of the Budget Committees.
We've seen how debts continued, the idea was suggested that this year it would be on day, but the historical ones have not been paid yet.
"I remind you that the agreement with banks and the Treasury was lost not because of me or someone else in these committees, it's very clear management problems," Severin said.
He added that after the activity report is rejected by the joint plenum, elections for a new Board of Directors will follow, and that will choose the general director of the institution.
I don’t know who will be proposed for this position.
Miracles won't happen.
It's important now to take political decisions to make it work.
I'm not gonna lie to you and say that some genius is going to show up and get in line.
I hope that those who decide, the parliament, through their vote will choose wisely the people who will lead the TVR.
You have to have people who know what's going on there, who have experience and have a lot of rectitude and respect for the institution and tradition.

I don't know who will, if you ask me what kind of qualities one needs to have, you've got to have a sense of common sense about the way you treat employees because we get a lot of petitions and complaints, you know, about firings.
"When you receive such reports 50, 60, 70, something is rotten and we are talking about the financial situation which is a disaster," the president of the Senate's culture committee concluded.

Although he did not appear before Parliament, TVR president-director general Stelian Tanase sent a letter to Chamber of Deputies president Valeriu Zgonea in which he requested the Parliament to consider a series of measures that could lead to the saving and guaranteeing of the economic and political independence of the public broadcaster, with indexing the TV tax among them.

In the letter, Stelian Tanase requested, besides the indexation of the TV tax, the modification and completion of HG 978/2003 concerning the tax for the public television service, in the sense of updating the provisions at the level of today's technological changes, as well as for the regulation of the procedure for controlling the payment of the TV tax and the detection of contraventions and the application of sanctions and penalties.
He also wishes for an order to be issued for all electricity supply companies to become SRTv tax collectors, with ANRE being involved in regulating this activity.

Stelian Tanase has called for the TVA tax rate on public television activities and the contribution to the CNC to be reduced from 15% to 3% and for the 41/1994 law to be amended to allow budgetary allocations/financing for the purchase of licenses for major cultural and sporting events - the World Football Championship, the Golden Stag, Eurovision.
He said the SRTv will face a cash crunch in the coming months, as labor laws mandate that employers honor court rulings, even if not final, and salary rights have priority over all other obligations.
The TVR administration has constantly made efforts to reduce personnel and TV production costs.

"Thereby, travel and other cost-generating activities have been reduced, a number of commercial contracts have been renegotiated, and TVR News was closed at the end of July", reads in the letter of the TVR president.
Tanase estimates that the disastrous financial situation can not be remedied only by their own efforts.

"Without the support of state institutions - the Government, Parliament, Presidency - the Romanian Television will find itself, sooner or later, unable to fulfill its public mission," it is mentioned in the letter.
