Surprise from one of the sexiest actors: I grew up in the kitchen
As Bradley Cooper is set to star as a chef in the movie "Burnt," the actor made a revelation his fans probably never saw coming.
In a recent interview, he said he grew more in the kitchen: "I worked most of my life as a cook."
He's revealed that he started in the kitchen at age 15, working at a Greek restaurant, and kept up the same line of work while he was in college.
The actor explained his mother is Italian, so his entire childhood was spent cooking with his Italian grandmother, ContactMusic reports.

Asked what his plans were at the time, Bradley Cooper said he was never a person who made plans for five years, "not even for two."
# Sentences
"I have no motivation to have a map," he said.
"I have dreams, things that you would laugh if I told you." He said, however, that what he wanted since childhood has been realized.
At 40 years old, the actor does admit that he sees himself directing in the near future, taking a cue from Clint Eastwood, who started directing at the same age.
Ponta Accused of Uncontrolled Calumnies and Irrational Statements

Hungarian Foreign Minister Peter Szijjarto harshly condemned, Wednesday morning, Romanian PM Victor Ponta's statements according to which the political leaders in Hungary are "by no means better than those in Syria, Libya or other countries from which refugees are fleeing".
"Yesterday Victor Ponta lost control, and through irrational statements he offended the whole of Hungary," the Hungarian foreign minister said in a statement.
Civilized European politicians don't make such unbridled calumnies.
"His remarks can only be explained by his having lost all support within Romanian domestic politics," the head of Hungarian diplomacy added, according to MTI.

In a Facebook post on Tuesday evening, Prime Minister Victor Ponta said he wished to draw attention and to sanction the behaviour of some high-ranking Hungarian government officials, who, in his opinion, "are a disgrace to the culture and the values of the European Union.
I don't want to answer to the challenges coming from Hungarian government representatives.

“They are a disgrace to the culture and values of the European Union – both in their anti-Semitic attitudes, and in the way they treat minorities of all kinds, and now in the way they are handling the refugee crisis!” Ponta wrote on Facebook.
The Romanian prime minister added that he is in favor of rational and sustainable solutions to the refugee crisis, noting that brutality and aggressive laws will not resolve the problem.

Barbed wire, aggressive laws, prisons and brutality will surely not solve the problem - they will just show that in Hungary, in the heart of Europe, there are politicians who are not better than those in Syria, Libya or other countries from which the refugees escaped!

"I believe in solidarity, in rational and sustainable solutions, and especially in the superiority of European values - what we see in Hungary these days is in total contradiction with these objectives and values!", the Romanian Prime Minister underscored.

Hungarian Foreign Minister Peter Szijjarto dismissed remarks by Romanian Prime Minister Victor Ponta about the handling of the refugee crisis by Hungary as "simple lies" on Tuesday, saying such statements were inappropriate for a 21st-century leader, the MTI news agency reports.

Hungary's foreign minister also said Tuesday that Romanian Prime Minister Victor Ponta's "extremist and mendacious" remarks are linked to Romania's internal political crisis and that Budapest expects an apology from the Romanian side.
Szijjarto referred to a statement made Monday by Romania's Prime Minister Victor Ponta.

What I have said and always say is that I am against xenophobic speeches, the idea of closing borders, that all those who come are terrorists, that they are stupidity of the Middle Ages, and I totally oppose this approach.
If we can receive more, we will receive, the problem is our logistical capacity to treat these people as people, not as our Hungarian neighbors do, with beatings and brutality.
"I do not agree with it," the Romanian prime minister said in a press conference in Targu-Jiu.

Also Tuesday, Peter Szijjarto said the Hungarian government has decided to start preparatory work on the ground on extending its fence at the border with Romania, to prepare for a possible change in the migrant route.
Later, Prime Minister Victor Ponta said Hungary's decision to erect fences at its borders did not solve anything and "took Hungary out of Europe."
What is the connection between Osama bin Laden and the crane collapse at Mecca
Saudi authorities say Saudi giant Binladin Group, owned by Osama bin Laden's family, is partially responsible for a crane collapse at Mecca's Grand Mosque last Friday that left 107 people dead.
According to an investigation committee, the company did not "follow safety regulations," the state-run Saudi Press agency (SPA) reported, BBC News reported.
Company executives have been barred from leaving the country pending the outcome of the investigation.
The company will also be barred from new public contracts.
The construction firm is owned by the family of former al-Qaida network leader Osama bin Laden.
The company was founded by Osama bin Laden's father 80 years ago and is now led by the former terrorist leader's brother, Bakr.
The Binladen Group has been working on the expansion of the Grand Mosque for 4 years to accommodate more pilgrims.
The accident took place Friday night during a thunderstorm, when a crane was apparently knocked down by powerful gusts of wind and fell on the eastern wing of the Grand Mosque in Mecca.
One hundred and seven people were killed and nearly 400 were injured in the accident.
How did Hagi shut down his opponents
Considered by many to be the greatest Romanian footballer of all time, Gheorghe Hagi has been labelled, after retiring as a player, as a poor coach, who can't achieve anything in his new role.
After bitter experiences at the national team, Steaua or Galatasaray, Hagi took, a year ago, the role of coach at Viitorul Constanta, the team he owns.
After just one year in charge of the club, the King has proven capable of transforming a team that was fighting relegation into a top team.
So after one year, with Hagi as a coach, The Future has registered 16 victories, 11 draws and 11 defeats.
Brazil's Former Presidential Chief-of-Staff to Stand Trial
Things have gotten even better for Viitorul in this season, as the team has climbed to second place in Romania's first division, with 19 points, one less than leader Astra Giurgiu.
Future has the best attack in the League 1, with 20 goals (equal to Astra), more than double than Steaua.

On the other hand, even if he brought more experienced players to the team, Hagi continued the policy of promoting young people, and in recent times Ianis Hagi or Hodorogea have appeared in the starting team.

The club's policy has made Viitorul a team to be watched by the foreign teams, so Hagi sold this summer for 1.5 million euros: Ianis Hagi (Fiorentina - 1 million euros) and Alexandru Mitrita (Bari - 500 thousand euros).
Along with Steaua, Viitorul is the only profitable team in Liga 1, according to the data from the Register of Commerce.
In the refugee crisis, Romania has played so far as a small country.
It is a legitimate strategy, but after that you cannot ask to be treated as the seventh country of the EU.
The big countries are coming up with solutions for the whole of the EU, said Cristian Ghinea, a member of the board of the Romanian Centre for European Policies.

In an interview for Ziare.com, Cristian Ghinea said that Europe cannot be transformed into a fortress, and purely police means will not work in this crisis: "Perhaps we have doubts about the quality of the values of these people."

But there are masses set in motion and we cannot turn history around.
 
Q: Masele nu sunt oameni, ele nu pot scrie, ele nu pot gândi.
A: The masses are not people, they cannot write, they cannot think.
Migration is a reality we have to adapt to, and adapt them to us as much as possible.
In Cristian Ghinea's opinion, we are in an extremely emotional moment, when politicians feel the need to show their muscles.

After that, Europeans will not be willing to give up on free movement, but the rules of the Schengen area need to be changed: "Schengen is now like an animal created in another epoch and not adapted to today's situation".
Where are we in the refugee crisis after this JAI council which actually did not resolved anything?
It is clear that the president of the EC in agreement with Donald Tusk didn't want to force a vote in the council.
All the polls had predicted he would have the votes he needed.
Before the Lisbon Treaty, the JHA operated on the principle of unanimity and any state could block any decision.
So things have been very little integrated in the areas of justice and home affairs.
Following Lisbon, the normal procedure is that the Commission takes the initiative, and the Council approves it voting 55%, i.e. 16 states, that represent 65% of the EU population.
The numbers said the votes were there.
But they didn't want to go forward.

Because it is a sensitive matter, there were even reactions in Germany against the policy of opening Chancellor Merkel and did not want many countries to appear as a reaction of the "EU sends us migrants on the head."
So they have postponed it, but the problem remains because obviously this wave is creating a huge problem for Schengen governance and we will probably see big changes there in the near future.
So the mandatory quotas were not really eliminated, it was just allowed to cool off for a while?

Yes, on the other hand, there is talk of greater involvement of the Frontex agency in managing external borders, which means a shift from the individual responsibility of the members who are at the external border of Schengen to the responsibility of the community agencies.
The Greek-Turkish border is in fact the German-Turkish border, and this wave of migrants has given the limits of the old Schengen system.
The Dublin principle could be abandoned, that migrants are the responsibility of the first state they enter, because it is unsustainable.
If Greece goes down, you can't say forever that it is Greece's own problem.
The problem is a shared one.
Precisely because the problem is common, is it possible a solution without a precise, maybe even mandatory, mechanism of sharing the effort of reception?
No one knows exactly how the quotas will work, if they get that far.
The question remains: what do you do with a person who does not want to go to Romania or Portugal, but to Sweden or Germany?
I don't think that European countries will start taking migrants: you go to country X or country Y.
There will probably be some kind of centralised processing centres in Greece or maybe Turkey, where the asylum applications are being dealt with.
Solutions like this are being worked on.
But the problem has no simple answer.

There are countries that have decades of experience in trying to integrate migrants, there are countries with no experience, like Romania, where the migrant issue will increase the xenophobic current.
We know that there are millions of people in Turkey, Lebanon and Jordan who are living in camps and are just starting to head to Europe.
An estimate says only 10% have managed to leave, winter is hard to cross the Mediterranean, but we expect next year a wave even larger.
What are we to do with these people?
My forecast is that we will get used to this problem, we will not look at it catastrophically.
You spoke about countries with greater or lesser experience.
Do you think there is any place that has really succeeded in integrating large groups from non-European cultures?
I see Maghrebis in France, Turks in Germany, they are all still ghettoized.
I wouldn't go for radical statements.
Sure, their integration is more difficult than in the case of other migration waves, but that doesn't mean they don't integrate at all.
There is this unassimilated part which is creating really big social problems in France, in Germany, in Britain.
But police-state tactics won't work.
Creating the fortress Europe is illusory.
Mechanisms for integration into European societies should be improved.
There were some errors in this.
We need to be more demanding.

We should ask these people to learn the language, to try to take on the values, not to stay with one foot in Europe and another in their homeland, even bringing their families there, including through convenience marriages.
But the imminent problem of these people should be separated from the long-term issue of their integration.
If others have failed in long-term integration, it doesn't mean that we should look at them drowning in the Mediterranean.
Maybe we have doubts about the quality of the values with which these people come.
And if there is intervention in Syria, which I don't think there will be, that doesn't mean the country will be rebuilt overnight and you can take them back.
Until the solutions come, we see fortresses inside Europe
Borders have been closed and border controls have been tightened.
Is the European Project in Danger?
The European project as such, no, the Schengen area as it was built, yes.
It was built with enough minimalism and by arranging the rules so that the pressure is too big on the countries where these migrants put their foot for the first time.
We are moving around freely, but everyone is dealing with its own problems.
In the face of such a wave, countries cannot cope.
When there are such waves of emotion, politicians want to show that they are doing something, but in the long run nothing much changes.
We do not yet have a much more draconian antiterror legislation in the EU than we did last year.
It is a wave of public emotion that is installed in both senses.
It is so volatile from week to week that you can't make decisions based on it.
We hear a lot of tough talk, tough talk from politicians back home who are trying to look tough.
And then you have the dramatic case of the child drowned in Turkey, and public opinion is moved.
After the excitement of the public, we will return to the reasons for which we created this space, this freedom of movement which is not only for humans, but also for goods.
This is the real european single market.
And I don't think Europeans will give up on this principle of the freedom of movement.
That there will be other rules is something else.
Schengen is now like an animal created in another era that was not adapted to the current situation.
How has Romania played so far in this crisis?
As a small country, which believes that, if it pulls its hat over its eyes and clogs up its ears, the topic (problem) will disappear.
Facing the reality of waves of migrants, you can choose to be part of the solution or say it's not your problem from a small country.
We did do that, it is a legitimate strategy, but then you cannot ask to be treated as the seventh country of the EU.
You are not and you don't play with a major country.
The big countries come with solutions for the entire EU, good or bad, we're not discussing their quality right now.
As did Poland.
On the other hand, the effect of this crisis is that Romanians' appetite for Schengen will decrease very much.
President Iohannis said it was probably good that we had not joined already.
So we are shifting from a desperation entry to a more pragmatic position, but the objective remains.
There is of course a risk that if Romania and Bulgaria join Schengen, migrants will see us as an alternative route.
This doesn't mean we shouldn't enter Schengen, but that we should be more pragmatic.

Romania will be part of the Schengen, but Schengen will exist but transformed in the sense that external borders will become a common responsibility, there will be common rules of accepting migrants, common rules of deporting those who do not receive asylum, common rules for the countries considered safe.
Ukraine's President Says No One Has Died in Ukraine Since Russia Turned Its Attention to Syria
Is there a link between the two outbreaks, a game of Russia?
Russia has a frustrated power behavior.
She thinks being a great power means annoying the Americans and the Europeans.
In that sense, yes, there is a connection.
Without the military and financial support of the Putin regime, the Assad regime would have fallen long ago.
And it was fortunate that they crashed before their principal opponent was the Islamic State.
For about two years, the struggle was between Assad's regime and secular and moderate Muslim militias backed by Arab Gulf countries and Westerners.
Then the Islamic State came up and now we don't know if we want the Assad regime to fall.
Russia can complicate things, but it cannot take part in the solution.
It creates pockets of instability and chaos it cannot shut down.
But you are a great power only if you have solutions.
Playing off-side is just a strategy to win time.
Probably Putin is waiting for offers to be made, to push the buttons to solve the situation.
The offers do not come in because the world is not convinced that he can solve in one way or another matters created by him.
But I do not agree with those theories that say that these people are driven by a hidden hand.
Let's not see Putin more powerful than he is.
What button will appear soon
Millions of Facebook users have become accustomed to the Like button, but now the social network is preparing to launch one opposite, a Dislike button.
Facebook founder and CEO Mark Zuckerberg, who announced the new feature on his account Tuesday, said it's been designed to help people express empathy.
Zuckerberg said the "dislike" button would reflect more of a shade of what a user is feeling than a simple vote.
But it raised the possibility that Facebook could become a less friendly place.
Zuckerberg said he wanted to avoid moments like when someone posts that they just got engaged, and someone else might "Dislike" it.
Users of the social network, which now has 1.5 billion active accounts, have long sought the ability to express negative emotions or empathize with something sad.
Mark Zuckerberg also said that it doesn't feel very comfortable for people to like events such as the refugee crisis or a death of a family member.
"You may not feel comfortable giving that post a Like", the Facebook representative said.
The new Facebook button hasn't been well received by everyone.
"There is already so much hatred on Facebook and social networks," commented Atiq Haneef from Afghanistan on New York Times' Facebook page where this article was posted.
"I will 'Dislike' the Dislike button," he said.
Atlanta microbiologist Roger Anderson says there is nothing wrong with liking a post on Facebook and encourages people to have several different opinions.
Debra Aho Williamson, social media analyst at eMarketer, noted that it is hard to imagine that a single button can convey a complex range of negative emotions.
Moreover, she says, the election campaign in America is coming up, and the "Dislike" button would create a total disaster.
Only 70 refugees enter Hungary in 24 hours
Hungary accepted only 70 migrants on Tuesday, a handful of the thousands who rushed to its southern border with Serbia, government adviser Gyorgy Bakondi said.

Hungary declared a state of emergency Tuesday in two counties along its border with Serbia due to the influx of refugees, closing a main border crossing and announcing it would build a fence along its border with Romania, the DPA reports.
Serbia reacted sharply to the move.
They said just yesterday they're going to seal the border to people who want to come across but not to people who want to apply for asylum.
"As you see, this is totally different," Serbia's Minister for Refugees, Aleksandar Vulin, said.
A record 5,809 migrants entered Hungary on Sunday before the introduction of new migration legislation, police said Monday.
Also, over 170,000 migrants from the Middle East and Africa have crossed into Hungary from Serbia in 2015.
Many try to avoid being registered and try to reach the West, especially Germany.
"New" county council building is about to fall.
Two contractors in insolvency
Massive investments made over the years to move the institution here are on the verge of collapse because they were repeatedly put on hold.
Two major contractors that worked on the project have filed for bankruptcy during the construction.
The County Council headquarters on Vasile Alecsandri Street will collapse by itself.
A year and a half after the consolidation and refunctionalization works were supposed to be completed, they're not even halfway finished.

The latest chapter in the stadium's saga was played out last week, when Romania's National Council for Contesting (CNSC) rejected a complaint from the company that wanted to take over the contract to build the technical design for the works to be done.
The initial project was drafted by Impex Romcatel SA.

Following the bankruptcy and halt of works, the procedures for negotiation were initiated, without a call for participation being announced, with Impex Romcatel being assigned to update the technical project and then a new auction for works was organized.
"However, the negotiations did not result in a contract, as the CJ deemed the proposed form to be disadvantageous to the institution", summarized Răzvan Timofciuc, the spokesman at the CJ.
The CJ's decision to suspend direct negotiations was challenged in court by Impex Romcatel.
The Iași court referred the complaint to the CNSC, which rejected it for being late.
That doesn't mean the CJ can begin searching for another design.
Impex Romcatel has the right to appeal the CNSC decision in the Court of Appeal, only after a final sentence of the latter can another project designer be considered.
As a result, work to shore up the building may not be able to start until early next year.
Our intention is to resume work as soon as possible.
In principle, the technical project should not take long to complete but we need to reach an agreement on the contract.
"We are waiting to see whether CNSC's decision will be appealed or not," Timofciuc said.
Work on the former Headquarters of the Police's consolidation started in 2011.
A first construction contract was terminated in April 2012, by which time 4.5 million lei had been spent on works.
The bidding process was restarted, and the contract was awarded to Moldoconstruct SA.
The company was, however, declared insolvent and the contract was consequently terminated after payments of RON 1.5 million were made.
The work has been completed by about 50%.
The initial cost estimate for the consolidation, refunctionalization and dormer window construction of the building was RON 7.7 million.
"I'm Done, I'll Tell Everything!" Former Cadastre Boss May Have Implicated Herself
An employee involved in the scandalous Cadastre's Office case signed a plea bargain, against deferred prison.
Most likely he will incriminate the rest of the defendants, headed by former boss, Narciza Nedelcu.
A consultant at the Real Estate Cadastre and Publicity Office (OCPI) of Iași, accused by the National Anticorruption Directorate (DNA) in a corruption case, has admitted facts.
The agreement on recognizing the deeds signed by Dumitru Dascălu was registered yesterday at the Tribunal in Iași, and the judges decided to give a ruling in this case on the 29th of September.
Dumitru Daniel Dascălu was charged with continuous intellectual fraud and agreed to serve two years in jail, deferred, as well as community service.

Regarding the deeds attributed to Dascălu, the prosecutors specified that, as a consultant of the Land Registry Office, together with other colleagues, "he drew up false minutes of acceptance, regarding the contracts of services agreed earlier by the O.C.P.I. Iaşi with the administrators of the SC Gauss SRL, SC Grup Cinci SRL, SC Topo Euro Cad SRL, SC Agenția de Ca­dastru și Topografie SRL și PFA Lipșa Ștefan companies, which attested, unrealistically, the fact that the contracted services were fully realized, while in reality these were not carried out and were not deposited at the O.C.P.I. Iași".

The former head of the OCPI, Narciza Nedelcu, and other former and current OCPI employees were sent to trial in the case, charged with billing for services provided to the companies, although the work was never done.
The damage exceeds 300,000 lei.
Adventures in the Stone Age

The president of Romanian Handball Federation, Alexandru Dedu, believes Romania can only host a major handball competition in 2024, and preparing the Romanian national women's handball team for qualifying for the Olympic Games is prohibitively expensive.

Alexandru Dedu, the President of the Romanian Handball Federation, said, yesterday, during a press conference, that it is a great honour that our country has three teams in the Champions League groups.

As for Romania's female handball national team, "the main objective is qualifying for the Rio Olympics, but before that, they need to pass two major tests, the World Championship and the Olympic qualifying tournament", Dedu also said.
We really want to qualify for the Olympic Games.
The demands are fantastic by the technical staff headed by Tomas Ryde.
The staff will comprise seven or eight persons.
He wants a second coach, a doctor, two masseurs, a goalkeeper coach, a physical trainer, the team manager.
They asked us for some things, some physical preparation materials, which we've never heard of.
All that just to get to the Olympics. And I'll do whatever it takes to get them.
This is a massive investment, lots of money.
But that's the road to performance.
Because at the moment we are in the stone age with preparation.
"The teams we are competing with have these materials and have had them for some time," Dedu said, adding the federation is trying to raise the money to buy them from MTS and COSR.
The Romanian Handball Federation president also referred to the infrastructure in Romania and to the possibility that the country might host a major handball competition.
We don't have a room in Bucharest.
Infrastructure is a problem and it is embarrassing that a European Gymnastics Championships is in doubt.
We must not forget that in other corners of the world entire Olympic villages were built in two years.
Before 1992, Barcelona's Olympic zone was a dump, but now it's a beauty spot.
It was the same in London, where the 2012 Olympics were a success in investment terms.
"In my vision, 2024 we can host a major competition," Dedu said.
He added that the international handball bodies are willing to grant Romania the organization of a major competition.
It is a priority for me to bring major handball competitions to Romania.
Mr. Gațu went there with a project, and the people gave their consent in principle, but they soon realized that the hall will never be built.
I have talked with EHF and said we are ready and they agreed to invite them to the first game in the new hall in Bucharest and then we will talk in detail.
"So we have the openness, both at EHF and IHF, but we don't have the infrastructure," the FRH official explained.

The former handball player avoided to evaluate the chances of the feminine teams CSM Bucharest and HCM Baia Mare to make it to the Final Four: "I requested all trainers to be reserved in their predictions, because if they don't come true they turn against them."
World Cup
Romanian rugby players to debut on September 23 against France

Romania's national rugby team captain Mihai Macovei said on Tuesday in a press conference that all the players are ready for the matches at the World Cup in England where they expect to get two wins: "We are all ready".
Me and my fellow colleagues are running at full throttle.
We trained to put in the best four games.
Everyone will have great expectations, because our goal is to win in two matches, against Canada and Italy.
All groups are hard and ours is as well.
Let's take it easy, first France and then we'll see.
Certainly, if we win against Canada, the match against Italy will be our final.
I cannot describe in words the joy of playing in the World Cup, it is the crowning of so many years of hard work.
I want to not disappoint anyone from the rugby family and bring good results home.
"We want you to be proud that a bunch of boys, a small family which is Romanian rugby, represent with pride the tricolor," Macovei said.

Romania's head coach Lynn Howells, who is experiencing his first World Cup as a coach, hopes to make the Romanians proud of the national rugby team: "It is a great honour for us to participate in this World Cup".
I'm sure the players are fit to participate in the tournament.
This is an extraordinary experience for me.
It is very important to me that I make Romanians proud at every match.
Haralambie Dumitras, the president of the Romanian Rugby Federation, is confident that Romanian players can confirm the progress they made in rugby in recent years.
We have a very difficult group and we want to confirm the progress made by the national team.
I wish the athletes success and I am confident that we will be up to the event.
"These guys started playing in the Romanian teams when they were 18-19 years old and have a strong bond, so they are a group of friends who have set out to realize a dream", Dumitraș said.

At the 2015 Rugby World Cup in England, Romania will play in Pool D, with following games scheduled: France on September 23 in London; Ireland on September 27 in London; Canada on October 6 in Leicester; Italy on October 11 in Exeter.
The competition will begin Friday at Twickenham Stadium in London with the England-Fiji Group A match.
Noi cursuri de cultură japoneză organizate la Universitatea "Al.I. Cuza"
About the arrangement of flowers in a vase, painting in ink, but also a carefree study of the fine arts of the Land of the Rising Sun you can learn at the courses organized by the students of Iași.

The Japanese Culture Students' Circle in Iasi organizes new Japanese culture courses (ikebana, sumie and fine arts) in October 2015 - June 2016, courses for both beginners and persons with experience.
The event will take place at the Center of European Studies at the Alexandru Ioan Cuza University in Iasi and will be organized to promote Japanese arts and culture, traditional and modern.
There is only one participation fee of 50 lei per month per person.
In addition to art classes the students will be able to take part in exhibitions and other cultural activities aimed at promoting beauty.
The Japanese culture courses we are offering are intended as an invitation to people to take the first few steps on the path to self-discovery through art.

"The interested people will be able to learn how to do harmonious floral sculptural creations (Ikebana), how to capture the soul of the surrounding elements in plastic compositions using the Japanese art of painting in ink (Sumie) or how to express their own individuality and creativity through the multiplex universe of arts (graphic, drawing, painting)," said Sorin Mazilu, the professor of these courses.
The courses are open to all those who are passionate about art, no matter their age or experience.
Registration ends on September 30, and those who want more information can call 0742.027.153 or e-mail studenticultura@gmail.com.
14 million lei given to Iasi's "St. Spiridon" Hospital at budget revision
What will this huge amount of money be spent on?
The "St. Spiridon" hospital received from the Health Ministry, after the budget rectification, about 14 million lei.

The money it will receive until the end of the year will be invested to modernize and refurbish clinics and invest in medical equipment and technology, for which the hospital has already started the procurement procedure.

Therefore, the health unit will be equipped with a new computer tomograph, with a new x-ray unit, with six sets used for surgical interventions, six properly equipped intensive care beds, an ophthalmic microscope and other equipment required for the medical act.
On the other hand, 5 million lei of the money received by the hospital will be directed to the construction and renovation works of "Great Ars".
The upgrade of the main segment will be finalized with the 500,000 lei from the state budget revision.

"In addition, in the coming days, we will receive the works from the overpass that connects the EPU to the clinics of cardiology, hepatology and gastroenterology to ensure decent transport of the patient from the EPU to neighboring clinics," the hospital's manager continued.
The hospital will soon welcome in its courtyard the Dermatology Clinic from Tatarsi, which will be organized in an outpatient clinic, under the same form under which it is currently functioning.
The clinic will operate in the area where there is an allergo-hematology-endocrinology clinic and will have about 30 beds.
Iași made a laughing stock by RATP controllers and a leaflet.
A Tourist's Ordeal
A family of tourists from Cluj came to Iasi to visit him, but the trip ended with a bitter promise.
After the experience, neither my wife nor I want to step ever again in your city.
Unwittingly, they bumped into the wrong information from leaflets, the unprofessional behavior of RAPT controllers, and, bonus, with a fine "because so says the law."
The couple arrived in Iasi a few days ago, they checked in a hotel in the city center and asked for tourist brochures.
They were given a flier with the RATP bus routes.
Armed with these maps, the couple visited Iasi.
But, two days ago, they were in Copou and they wanted to get to Palas Mall.
As there was no ticket machine in the station near Copou Park, they relied on what was printed on the leaflet: that you can buy tickets by SMS.
Nobody told them that this service is no longer available.
Confident in the flyer, they got on a bus and tried to text according to the instructions on the flyer.
Unfortunately for them, a team of RATP ticket inspectors appeared.
They said that it no longer exists and that it has been announced in the press that it has been cancelled.
How should I know what the local press wrote, I came to visit the city one day before?
I talked to the controllers, I explained to them the situation, they said they did not care, it was not their problem.
His attitude was very defiant.
They said all they could do is give us a single fine instead of two (one for me and one for my wife).
Ovidiu tells me he did what he could to avoid spending his day at the police station. “I paid, I didn't want to spoil my day by having to go to the police and make a statement!” he says.
The family was fined because of the erroneous information on the brochure and the controllers who "applied the law to the letter".
This is not correct and I filed a complaint to the RATP Iasi to have my money back.
It's not about the money, it's not an exagerated amount, but the idea is that I felt cheated.
Bad luck for Vaslui rapists.
They had an accident and were placed under pre-trial detention
The trial of seven rapists from Vaslui was moved, yesterday, to the Court of Appeals, Iasi.
A judge in Iași heard the first hearing in a closed session in which seven young men accused of having ridiculed an 18-year-old girl asked to be released.
Before the actual hearing, one of Iasi judges assigned to the case, Viorel Munteanu filed a recusal request, which was admitted by his colleagues at court.

The magistrate served until last summer at Vaslui Tribunal, where he was the president of the Criminal Section and admitted the contestation filed by four of the defendants, ordering their placement under house arrest.
It is currently being handled by a panel made up of judges Maricica Mititelu and Geta Sandu.
Previously, Judge Dan Anton recused himself from the case, citing a personal relationship with one of the defendants, whose son is dating his daughter.
The two judges decided that the rapists from Vaslui will remain in pre-trial detention.
The youths will remain in jail for at least another 30 days, when judges will revisit the possibility of releasing them.
The next hearing will be held at the Iasi Court of Appeal on October 6.
Before reaching the Court of Appeals in Iasi, the van in which the rapists from Vaslui were transported was involved in an accident in the district of Păcurari, the car entering Iasi on the beltway.
The Iveco van in which the seven rapists were being transported hit a Volkswagen car which had come out of Cantacuzino Street, and the driver tried to steer left.
The van was coming from Păcurari end.
The car entered Iasi through here because the Penitentiary Administration employees preferred the route from Vaslui to Iasi through Grajduri, then on the ring road.
This cut the journey by a few kilometers.
The prisoners' escort called for another vehicle to take the prisoners after the first one was damaged in the collision.
Shortly afterwards, a van from the Maximum Security Penitentiary in Iași was dispatched to the scene, where the seven prisoners were taken and transported to the Appelate Court.
None of the arrested was injured in the accident.
To exchange the prisoners, guards surrounded the rear of the vehicles, and the prisoners emerged two by two from the vans.

"The incident was not reported to the police because the drivers of the two vehicles reached an amicable agreement concerning the damages that must be paid," said Chief Commissioner Madalin Taranu of the County Police Inspectorate.
Great migrations
Romania is not and will not be prepared for what will come next.
But Europe?

Let me just say this from the beginning, loud and clear: the 7,000 refugees Romania should and must naturalize are indeed a non-significant number, but huge in comparison to the Romanian state's capacity to manage such a project.
Even the voluntary intake of some 1500 souls proposed by Bucharest far exceeds our good intentions of solidarity with the European Union expressed in recent months.
If any of these migrants actually agree to settle in our villages, the chances to rapidly integrate them into Romanian society are extremely small.
I'm sure they were the first to lose their patience.
Infested with racketeers and paralyzed by venal political class, the Romanian state proves to be impotent in all areas.
The inability to integrate the Roma is just a banal example.

Besides, governments of any color have not been able to absorb European funds, build roads, kindergartens or modern schools, provide decent medical care, clean up the streets, create good, paid jobs or keep their own generation at home.
Why would refugees be resettled in the country from which they are fleeing?
But what is most striking is the hypocrisy with which such a crisis is treated.
We are first confronted by the bellicose hypocrisy of the powerful EU states, which show themselves to be most generous when it comes to sharing their woes with smaller countries.

Then comes the cowardly hypocrisy of the Romanians who, although they have millions of relatives scattered all over the world, still cannot accept the other - of another language, another religion, another blood.
Probably for fear that someone would steal their national being.

Finally, there is the hypocrisy of many migrants who, although they invoke the horrors of war as their motive for leaving, do not accept any destination for their exodus other than Germany or the Nordic countries.
But not all the refugees are Syrians, and Pakistan is at peace.
Moreover, the simplistic way the crisis is being analyzed is nothing short of a farce.
Some want to tackle the root causes, betting on the political correctness card, and call for peace and investments in the homelands of the migrants.
But in Romania peace has come, and even some foreign capital comes into the national economy - but that doesn't stop tens of thousands of Romanians from leaving the country every year.
Why they leave?
In the crisis, the European Union has revealed itself as a rigid, divided and outdated construction.
We were lamenting the fact that Romania is incapable of inventing a project for the country, and now it turns out that the EU does not have a plan for the future either.
And improvisations and threats do not help.
So what's the point of the EU, if the only advantage Romanians enjoyed - the freedom to travel - could be jeopardized because of the waves of refugees flooding the borders?
At some point, the war in Syria will end.
The migrant crisis is different, however.
In the coming decades, overpopulation, poverty, climate change, resource depletion and so on will push millions of desperate migrants, from Asia and especially Africa, towards a better life.
With such politicians, Romania is not and will never be prepared for what is to come.
7,000 euro per year to rent Pogor Club.
The destination is, in practice, imposed
The licensing round covers a period of 10 years.
After seven years in which it remained closed, the club in the courtyard of the Romanian Literature Museum is being offered for concession by the Bucharest District Council for a period of 10 years.
Construction has a useful area of 134 square meters, on two levels of caves.
The court accepts as destinations, only literary cafe, bookstore or other cultural activities.
The property was valued at €68,300, with the starting bid at €6,830 per annum, with a bid increment of €25.

The concessionaire will have to exploit continuously and permanently the building, covering in full the costs of rehabilitation and restoration of the building, in accordance with the technical project to be developed.

The Pogor House club building is in an advanced state of degradation due to the fact that during the period in which this space was used as a public eating facility and even after its evacuation current repair and maintenance works were not performed as are necessary during the exploitation of a building, in the tender documentation.
Offers to buy the club are expected until September 18.
Two brothers from Tomești swallowed sleeping pills.
They were taken to hospital
Two brothers, aged 9 and 11, from Tomești have swallowed several Diazepam pills.
They found the pills in the house and took them out of curiosity.
Their mother was undergoing treatment and the medicines were not hidden.
The children were rushed to the "Saint Mary" Hospital in Iași.

They are in stable condition, according to the doctors.

EXCLUSIVE: A heart-wrenching meeting.
At 20, He Got A Brave Gift: His Biological Parents

Lost in hospital in unclear circumstances in the fog of the 1990s, when she was only two months old, sickly and helpless, and then adopted by a wealthy family in Italy in the years when adoption was vaguely regulated, a young Iasi girl, now a beautiful blonde, met yesterday in Iasi with her biological parents from a village in the county, after almost two decades in which no one knew anything about each other.
Crina will turn 20 this year and her adoptive parents in Palermo decided to give their beloved daughter an amazing and brave gift: a trip to Romania, in Iasi, to explore her unclear past.
"Ziarul de Iași", who have assisted in the efforts to find the family of origin on the basis of a few extremely vague clues, have witnessed these meetings which are heart-breaking in effect.
The reporters' observations, the witnesses' emotions, their testimonies, their reactions are absolutely moving and overwhelming.
Crina's story starts 20 years ago in the village of Ruginoasa, Iasi county, when she was only two months old.
At that time, due to a health problem, the girl had to be hospitalized in the town.
At home there began to be misunderstandings between parents, and the mother was forced to leave the home.
He decided to keep the girl and to send me home.
He stopped the girl and since then I've known nothing.
"When I found out she was in hospital it was too late," said Alina, the girl's birth mother, who was too upset to give her surname.
Crina was hospitalised together with her grandmother at the municipal hospital in Pascani, and her father, Costica Balcan, left for work in the city of Alexandria, Teleorman County.
Their lives would part forever.
They couldn't find Crina at the hospital
After his wife's admission, the father moved to another city to work, and returned after six months.
Meanwhile, the girl had been transferred to hospital in Iasi, and when the father returned, he could not find her.
I think the girl had been in the hospital for almost nine months.
"She probably thought she was abandoned," says one of the grandchildren.
Because of financial constraints, the girl's grandmother could not come with Crina to Iași, so the girl was left in the care of the medical staff.

As nobody showed any interest in the child's fate in all that time, she was taken over by the General Direction for Social Assistance and Child Protection in Iasi, which then placed her with a foster home in Bucium.
Back then, the rules on abandonment and adoption were a lot more relaxed than they are in Romania today.
The embryo was found in the Bucium Center by an Italian Salvadore and his wife, a couple from Palermo who wanted to have a baby but couldn't.
They fell in love with the blonde Crina, and after some time she was to move permanently with them in Italy.
The little one was already almost two years old, by the time the adoption procedures were completed.
I saw Crina and I felt that she was our girl.
"As if my wife gave her life," says Salvadore, the adoptive father, smiling as he holds the frail girl's hand in his.
Back home, Crina's parents, Alina and Costică, continued separate searches, each wherever they could.
The father asked the authorities from Ruginoasa but he did not get any answer where his child could be.
Police then told them she may have died, but in Iasi the parents discovered what had actually happened to their daughter.
When we looked for her here, the Tribunal told us that she had gone to Italy, to Palermo.
And I have not had time to look for one.
We prayed to God that it will be fine.
I have thought of her all these years but there has been no way to look for her.
"It's hard," Crina's biological mother tells us through tears.
But, even years later, the parents in Ruginoasa have not been forgotten.
In Italy, Salvadore and his wife explained to their daughter where she came from and that her past connects her to Romania.
I was young when I found out.
I guess I was five or six years old.
I reacted like a child. I was curious.
"I wanted to meet my parents from Romania," said Crina happily.
And her dream was about to come true.

In March this year, anti-drug chief Romica Ichim, director of the centre for anti-drug prevention, assessment and counselling in the city of Iasi, was contacted by a friend in Italy who explained Salvadore's desire to find Crina's biological family.
And the searches had started with just one name.
After we had the request from our partners in Italy, we started the first steps.
I only had a name, Costică Balcan, and the town, Ruginoasa.
Shortly after, we had an activity with the local government and we were able to ask if there's a place with the given name.
They gave me some directions, but the person they found was not the person I was looking for.
"It took us almost a month to find the father of the girl", says chief commissioner Romică Ichim.
It took the authorities over three months to find Costel and Alina, especially because they each lived in a different place.
We started the procedures in March, and finalized the identification of biological parents and the talks in June-July.
"In September, we decided to have a first meeting," added Romică Ichim.
This past weekend, Alina and Costică saw their lost daughter for the first time in 20 years in the Iași hospital hallway.
The father was overcome with emotion and was barely able to hold back tears. His hands were shaking uncontrollably.
He barely exchanged words with those around him.
A week before the meeting he could hardly sleep.
He was so excited, trembling.
"To see your child after so many years is something", says a granddaughter, who came with Costica from Ruginoasa.
Crina's Meeting with Her Biological Mother and Brother

In his conversation with his daughter, who is going to study at a well-regarded university in Italy, Costică Balcan told him, among other things, that if she ever wanted to return to him, in the village, she should come quietly: he can give her some sheep, goats, so she can find a boy from the village and start a household.
The mother is also deeply moved and she can hardly believe that this could happen to her.
I am very emoționată.
I didn't believe it would happen.
I saw such cases on TV, I've been thinking about this for years, I hoped, but I never thought that I could be such too.
There are very big emotions.
If she could forgive me.
I hope we'll visit each other in the future.
'I hope we can keep in touch,' says Alina, Crina's mother, with tears in her eyes as she holds a handkerchief tightly.
He's also hiding tears of joy because he'll see his daughter in a short time after so much bitterness.
Crina, who will be turning 20 in a couple of days this month, on the other hand, tries to calm herself down like an emotional child.
She doesn't know what to expect, but she's got a general idea about her biological parents.
I think they are young, but before the meeting she tries to gather her thoughts, because she has a lot to say, but nothing to reproach.
My parents are two moms and two dads.
But my parents are the ones who raised me.
It will be a beautiful meeting, a wonderful experience.
"I hope I will have a good memory with them, because now there are so many things to tell", Crina confides.
The First Family Reunion in Iasi
In Union Square, under a late summer sky, the family from Ruginoasa is once again uniting its fate with their daughter from Palermo.
Cristina has now turned 20, she is finishing high school, following the Italian school model, but she might start a new chapter with Alina and Costică, her biological parents.
They are no longer separated by borders or countries, but only by a barrier: language.
Over which, with the help of a translator, an Italian owner of a local in central Iași, they passed easily.
Those who arranged to make this meeting possible say it is the first time such an event was made, and that, in the future, if the opportunity arises, they will do it again.
It's the first time such an event has been held and I'm happy this one is a success.
We at the Centre have different activities, and most often we are associated as an institution that deals only with users, people dependent on drugs.
But we're trying to give something good back to society.

"If I am asked again to be a part of such an event, I will do so with great pleasure", smilingly says Romică Ichim, the director of Iași Regional Center for Drug Prevention, Assessment and Counselling (CREDIS).
Behind her, the Balkan family, with Crina in the middle, walks away, telling the story.
It makes sense: they have much to tell each other.
Gun-free truce, yesterday, at the PSD.
Everybody is taking a breather
The camps in the Iasi branch of the PSD have reached a ceasefire with a gun to hand.
After several rounds of talks, held Friday through Sunday, the first and most tense of which, the PSD leaders agreed to temporarily suspend hostilities.
Under pressure from Social Democratic Party (PSD) Chairman Liviu Dragnea to present a united front, the PSD's Iasi chapter will send him a whole list of potential candidates for party posts.
Far from being over, the internal war in the party seems to have taken just a break to allow the combatants a breather.
Dragnea did not give an ultimatum.
He delivered a very simple and current message in the current circumstances: try to find a solution so as not to endanger the party.
We have party elections on October 3rd.
All positions will be made available to those who will desire them.
"Until then, we will stay within the existing structure," interim mayor Mihai Chirica said.
The two days of talks over the weekend yielded only the conclusion that nothing certain had been agreed.
At the October elections for the presidency of the county branch of the Social Democratic Party it is expected to be bitter competition.

The shortlist of potential candidates for the party's top position in Iasi includes State Secretary Maricel Popa, Senator Florin Constantinescu, Senator Sorin Lazăr, County Councilor Vasile Câtea, and Interim County Council President Victorel Lupu.
Schitu Duca mayor Mihai Mihalache could also be charged.
Another option is that of the leader of the PSD county councilors, Cristian Stanciu, in case Lupu will not join in the race, sources within the party saying that he is not interested in the position.
The only name not mentioned by any of the participants in the negotiations in the past days is that of former party leader, mayor Gheorghe Nichita.
The list of candidates is open.

Under the rules, even on election day candidates can be filed, and it would not surprise anyone if it happened.
 
Q: În cazul în care își va păstra poziția, el va fi primul președinte de la căderea dictaturii militare în 1985 care reușește să se recadidateze.
A: If he keeps his position, he will be the first president since the fall of the military dictatorship in 1985 to succeed in running for re-election.

"It is important that we stay united, and we will stay united even after October 3, when we will have a new Executive Office, a new County Permanent Office and all new management structures," Câtea said.
Until the organization of internal elections, the county branch of PSD will be led by Victorel Lupu, a close friend of Nichita and Stanciu.
Lupu is on leave until the 29th, however, and preparations for the elections will be handled by the branch executive secretary, Mihail Popescu, who is not on good terms with the Nichita camp.
Contacted by phone, Cristian Stanciu described the discussions of the past few days as leading to "a partial consensus".
There is a broad willingness to keep balance and unity in the party.
A partial consensus was reached to back a unified team to deal with the county.
"However, on the other hand, there are several options regarding the intentions concerning candidacy for the presidency of the PSD Iași, the list remaining open," said Stanciu.
Iași judge dismissed rape charges for lack of marriage
Seven young men from Vaslui county who were convicted of rape will go to the Court of Appeal in Iasi today.

The Vaslui defendants sentenced to between five years and eight months and eight years and four months will today present their arguments for their release, after the trial court, the Vaslui Court of Law, established their immediate incarceration upon sentencing.
The case was filed at the appeals court late last week, with Judge Dan Anton filing a request to abstain from the case, which was accepted by his peers.
Anton cited the fact that one of the defendants' lawyers, Bogdan Luca, is the common-law husband of his attorney daughter, Dana Anton.
Luca is defending Silviu Ovidiu Balan, who received the largest sentence in this case.
The justification for the sentence
The Vaslui court magistrate who sentenced the seven youths last week justified the ruling in a statement released Friday.

In a reasoning, the judge talked about the defiant reaction of the defendants, as well as of those who supported them, stressing that such attitudes create a strong feeling of indignation among the public opinion.

"The court finds that after the placement under house arrest of the preventive measure of judicial control, a restrictive measure of freedom but not a measure of deprivation of liberty, under the impact of the attitude of the accused, of families and local supporters of them, there was felt at the level of local and national communities a strong sense of indignation with regard to the fact that persons accused of serious crimes are tried under a less restrictive measure," reads the motivation of the Vaslui Court.
Also, the magistrates dismissed the main defence of the seven accused who, during the trial, argued that the girl they raped was "not a saint."

"The court emphasizes that it is irrelevant the moral quality of the injured party, which the defendants wanted to highlight through the defenses they put forward, since the physical and sexual freedom of a person cannot be violated under any circumstances", the reasoning document further reads.
Corbyn, Brexit, and Europe's Future
For economic and demographic reasons, the prosperity that has been enjoyed over the past few decades cannot be sustained in the years ahead.
Until Saturday, few people in Romania probably knew who Jeremy Corbyn was.
Even today, as he becomes the new leader of Britain's Labour Party, many are wondering how much the election of a politician who is not, after all, in a position of decision can affect us.
Jeremy Corbyn is Labour's most leftwing leader since the second world war.

A declared Marxist, anti-monarchist (he once told then British Prime Minister Tony Blair to get the royal family out of Buckingham Palace), a fierce anti-American and a Vladimir Putin sympathizer (he was regularly invited to comment on political events by the “Russia Today” television channel), and a supporter of the Hezbollah and Hamas terrorist groups, he wants Britain to give up nuclear weapons and pull out of NATO and the EU.
For Corbyn, who at the time called the killing of Osama bin Laden a tragedy, ISIS is almost preferable to the U.S.
Like all populist demagogues, Corbyn has, of course, miraculous anti-austerity solutions.
The sort of things Tsipras was promising in Greece, right up until the moment he came face to face with the real world and economic realities.
The Labour leader's economic plan includes massive renationalisations and the printing of money to fund development projects and pay for generous social benefits.
Sure, one might wonder why the solution of printing money is not universally adopted, we would then have a global general prosperity! But who would bother with such details?

Sure, we can tax the bankers, who are sort of the left's public enemy number one, but as we've seen time and time again, not just in former Communist states or in Ecuador or Venezuela, but also in France, at the beginning of the Mitterand and Hollande administrations.
The extra money is quickly gobbled up by the grandiose, unfunded promises made by populist demagogues.
As Margaret Thatcher so famously said, "The problem with socialism is that eventually you run out of other people's money."
Few give Jeremy Corbyn any real chance to become prime minister,
In the early 1980s another left-wing radical, Michael Foot, albeit not as extreme in his beliefs as the new Labour leader, had failed miserably at the polls.
And there was still a working class in Britain, in the classic sense of the word - a relatively substantial and structured working class.
And trade unions were much more powerful than they are now.
In the context of the new industrial landscape, in which services dominate the workforce and extensive automation has made industry less labor-intensive, Corbyn's rhetoric has limited appeal.
But even from the opposition, he can influence important developments that can directly affect us.
In its latest edition Financial Times considers that the election of Corbyn increases the chances of Brexit, respectively exiting the UK from the EU.
The new Labour leader has been a consistent opponent of Britain's EU membership.
In the eyes of radical Left Brussels is the agent of international capitalism and a promoter of globalization that has imposed austerity on the poor.

When you combine this kind of thinking with the ideas of the far right, with anti-immigration rhetoric and you look at the refugee crisis that is shaking the EU to its foundations, you come up with an explosive mix.
And not just for Britain.

But if the British decide in the referendum, which is due to take place by 2017, to leave the Union, the loss of capital symbolic for the entire European project and deep rifts created within it by the euro crisis and now that of refugees, between North and South, between East and West, leaves room for scenarios of the most worrying.
All the more so since, for a whole series of member states, London was a counterbalance to the Franco-German axis (in which anyway Berlin was becoming the dominant actor).
It is true that Britain's business community, the City, are strong advocates of Britain remaining in the EU.
But today's Europe is no longer what it was.
There is a lot of resentment and it's growing by the week.

The problem is that Brussels, we really had a recent specimen in Jean-Claude Juncker's speech, tends more and more to take major decisions over the head of the great majority of the member states consulting with just a few European powers, mainly Germany.
And this happens as the electoral support for anti-system and anti-immigration parties which are also eurosceptic grows spectacularly all over the continent.
In other words, the emotional climate of negative charge has reached higher levels than ever.
So the Financial Times' conclusion about the likelihood of a Brexit.
Pro-EU option is based on a cold calculation based on national interests.
If voters take the cerebral decision, Britain will stay in the EU.
But Corbyn's victory reminds us of the power of emotion in current politics.
And Eastern Europe can be significantly impacted by such major developments.

Especially if, as expected, we will witness a much more pronounced integration of the Eurozone, which will push most of the region's states even further to the periphery of Europe's interest and decision-making process.
Corbyn, Tsipras and Syriza in Greece, Podemos in Spain, even Bernie Sanders in the United States are all feeding populist rhetoric from the frustrations accumulated in Western societies.
For economic and demographic reasons, the prosperity that has been enjoyed for the last few decades and the generous social benefits cannot continue as it has in the years to come.

Under the explosive pressure of the dual crisis - euro zone, immigration - both caused by impromptu decisions that took into account only the integrationist political ambitions, not peoples' and governments' capacities and willingness in Europe to face such challenges, the continent's turbulence, intra-EU tension will increase in intensity and can majorly affect Romania's situation.
It is hard to rule out anything from the standpoint of possible scenarios.
The question is whether our main political leaders are able to face such complicated situations.
Constantin Brâncuși, the peasant god.
Rockefeller: "How can I help you?"
Brâncuși: "Sweep the studio as well!"
The great sculptor had a big dream: to be somebody, to become famous and to be heard about all over the world.
But behind all of that renown is something almost forgotten in our era of millions of success stories, a recipe for making it in life.
That something has a name.
It is called "Truda"
Constantin Brâncuși, cunoscut ca unul dintre cei mai importanți artiști moderniști, a fost un sculptor și pictor român.
What else is there to say, actually?
His figure appeared on banknotes.
Recently, a well-known bank in Romania has hired an actor to play in an advertising clip.
Brancusi has been producing and delivering money for almost 60 years after his death.
There are hundreds of streets and highways in Romania named after him.
In fact, even the author of this text lives in one of these streets.
But when she goes outside with her child, she hears the following instructions: "Let's go to the park, to Brancusi."
The country is littered with his statues.
There are very few Romanian personalities whose works are known by so many people, from children to seniors.
Brancusi's ability to infiltrate is huge.
The Communists were not able to uproot him from the memory and culture of Romania.
His quotes now litter the internet, getting hundreds of thousands of likes and shares.
And then, again, what would be left to say, to write about this person?
Seen from the heap of books and articles that attempt to reconstruct his destiny, Brancusi's life seems almost fantastic, totally improbable.
You know, there are those who'll tell you that if you weren't lucky enough to be born in a big city, or in a well-off family, your chances of success in life are near zero.
The life of Brâncuși is the perfect counterexample.
And maybe therein lies the key.
Maybe the following text should start from here.
With a sentence, however despicable it might be.
Forget the dumb success stories that are delivered to you daily in newspapers and on television.
Look closely at this man's face.
Would you like to know how it managed to succeed in life, how, today, he heard the whole world?
It's simple.
He worked all his life to be someone.
It has.
Constantin Brancusi was born on February 19, 1876, in Hobita, a small village near the town of Targu Jiu, in the county of Gorj, at the foothills of the Carpathians.
He is the fifth child of Maria and Radu Nicolae Brâncuși.
Coming from a prosperous peasant family, Brâncuși lived a modest life, but one which he gathered the early landmarks that would later guide his artistic vision.
Recalling his childhood and the places he grew up in, the artist would say in a meeting with Petre Țuțea in Paris in 1933, "Back then, life was beautiful and harmonious."
For millennia, people lived happy patriarchal lives.
Everything went on peacefully from one season to another.
And do you know why that changed?
The great city civilization has reached us.
But Brancusi's childhood was far from idyllic.

One of the most relevant moments in these first years of life is extremely suggestive for his future sculpture career, as it illustrates the combination of purity and violence which characterised the sculptor's years spent in his hometown.
The moment is recounted in the book "Brâncuși. A Biography", written by Alexandru Buican.
In 1879, Constantin Brancusi was three years old.

That fall, when the moonshine was being made, he watched the tasters as they sipped the liquid to see if the process was getting done right, Brancusi took advantage of a moment of general inattention.
He filled his palms with brandy and drank it in one go.
He falls asleep almost instantly.
First people just notice after a few minutes.
His mother goes into hysterics, thinking her son is dead.
At night, when his father Radu comes back home from the vineyard, accompanied by musicians, he sees the desperate signs of the people who are waiting eagerly.
The party is immediately turned into a wake.
The father is already thinking about the funeral.
Yet someone thinks it good to call it Baba Brândușa, a doctor and servant of the Brâncușis.
Brândușa checks the child's breath, then she puts under his nose horse dung, collected from nearby.
The child sneezed violently.
The world applauds.
While the boy sleeps off his drunkenness, the party with the gypsies continues with even more vigor.
The next day, father and son meet through the orchard.
Radu Brâncuși asked Constantin to gather some willow twigs and bring them to him.
The father puts the child upside down and beats him with the twigs the boy brings so he can remember.
While feeling the sting of the blows, little Brâncuși has a revelation that the world can be looked from a different perspective and that the things around us can appear upside down.
Especially the sun's position, unlike the familiar one, makes him wonder, as he would admit in old age, whether perhaps the star itself was participating in his turmoil.
Did the sun itself frown as darkly as his father had done at the thought of what had occurred?
At this time the city is not working
A lawmaker calls on politicians to remember those who voted for them.
Independent Deputy Viorel Blăjuț called on the Social Democratic Party (PSD) and the National Liberal Party (PNL) to cease their internal fighting and reorient their agenda toward the electorate.
What we see now on our political stage is a great divide and nothing more.
I haven't seen anything from the USL project from 2012 that has continued.
Neither the highway nor the Regional Emergency Hospital, we just see how politicians argue about the possible locations according to the real estate interests.
Let's put politics aside, let's gather and talk.
It is not working at the moment though.
"When you are busy with internal war, you are no longer able to govern," Blajut said.

He said that the current political class has disappointed the Iaşi electorate, with the consequence that the future voter turnout in local elections will be very low, around 30%, representing the loyal electorate of the parties.
The MP also thinks that voters will turn to traditional parties, expressing reservation towards new political initiatives, such as the "For Iaşi" party, which will be launched today.
Local parties have very little chance to make it to parliament and they would only split the right-wing electorate, not PSD's.
Such parties rely on civic activism, which is usually right-wing.
"The right is being further fragmented, which is not good for anyone, not even for the PSD," Blajut said.
He says he is not interested in a candidacy in next year's local elections, denying rumors of his intention to run for mayor.
I have already said that I do not want to run for local office.
I'm still thinking if I'll continue as a deputy and in the future mandate.
I tried to appeal to unity for Iasi during the discussions in the hallways, with the other parliamentarians, and I was accused of wanting to build up my image.
I don't want to, but we can't go on like this.

"If people have voted for us, it does not mean that they are stupid enough not to vote for us if they do not see anything", said Blăjuț, who believes that the main reason why voters have grown disinterested with politics is the hypocrisy of the elected officials.
A colleague from Tătărași said he doesn't have enough money and has to go by bus.
Let's not be hypocrites.
There is no small money.
I am sometimes ashamed to pick up the money from the cashier.
At the end of the term I will make a report of everything I spent, excluding the salaries of the staff and the maintenance of the cabinet.
I happened to raise 30,000 lei in a month, with all transport, accommodation and other vouchers.
"It's pure hypocrisy for a lawmaker to say they are not paid enough," concluded Blăjuț.
